Comment: Queen's Pawn is my favored opening with white
Heading for an Indian Defense perhaps
Normally I would 2. c4 here for the Queen's Pawn Gambit but I decided to play away from my strength perhaps finding our way into a French
Out comes the Queen which is generally frowned upon
Out of anything with which I'm familiar I tried to apply the strategy that my mentor (OldGus here at GameKnot) suggests. Make developing moves that put pieces in good positions
Now looking French like
I'm thinking about eventuall Bg5 and trapping the queen or forcing a lot of queen defensive moves

My opponent cuts off all retreating squares making my life easier. It did take me some time to figure out 5. Bg5 was no longer the best move. If you see a good move, always look around and try and fine one better.
Trapping the queen
Making the best of a bad situation
Already with eyes towards a king side attack
Preparing to fianchetto and castle. The Bishop on g7 looks weak to me because of my strong pawn structure blocking the diagonal
Development and threatening 8. Bxe7 preventing castling
A second knight move aiming for Nb4 possibly
Preventing the knight from making headway
Relieving the pin
Just getting my pieces out. I didn't feel an urgency to castle at this point
Threatening 10. Nxc2 winning the rook with a pin
Preventing the pin. I went long side castle here because my Bishop on g5 prevents my opponent from long side castling and my king side attack is already rolling
Hoping to win a pawn with 11. Nxb5 Nxa2+ but not seeing the continuation I think
